item.description:
Since our first experimental mashup went so swimmingly (wouldn't you say?), let's try it again.

This time, I'd suggest we talk about the works of two largely unknown master storytellers.

Lydia Davis, a living author of eccentric stories unparalleled in originality, economy, and humor. 

Example. Her story Mother's Reaction to My Travel Plans consists of just this line: "Gainesville! It's too bad your cousin is dead!"

In The Landing she writes about a particularly memorable flight.

http://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/books/9013382/Exclusive-Lydia-Davis-story-The-Landing.html

(If you find yourself developing an appetite for her stories, also read Letter to a Funeral Parlor http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=120953449)

Then we have Bruno Schulz, a dead author whose surviving work is in equal measure scant and unique.

The Father's Last Escape is part of his novelistic collection of short stories Street of Crocodiles, and it preoccupies itself with a father who seems to die in installements.  As The New Yorker notes: "The dead father appears as a presence that occupies the objects of the house. The wallpaper takes on his mannerisms; his old fur coat starts to breathe. Then one day the family finds a crab-like creature on the stairs and they recognize it at once as the father’s latest manifestation. The narrator simultaneously draws attention to and brushes aside the oddity of this occurrence: 'In spite of the metamorphosis, the resemblance was incredible.'"

 http://www.newyorker.com/online/blogs/books/2012/02/fiction-podcast-nicole-krauss-reads-bruno-schulz.html#ixzz1qFrpVhwH

So, let's discuss these stories side by side and see what insights percolate to the surface.

group.name: Classic Books: Book Club for Die-hard Readers

item.name: Mashup: Lydia Davis' "The Landing"+ Bruno Schulz's "Father's Last Escape"
